fields.name: Ultras White Knights
fields.description: Ultras White Knights (UWK) are the main supporters’ group of Zamalek SC in Cairo, Egypt, founded in 2007. They are known for their passionate support, spectacular tifos, and heavy use of flares and smoke in stadiums, creating one of the most intense atmospheres in African football. Beyond football, they became a political force during Egypt’s 2011 revolution, clashing frequently with security forces and expressing opposition to government repression, which led to bans and persecution of their members. Their fiercest rivalry is with Ultras Ahlawy of Al Ahly, forming one of the most heated Ultras rivalries in the world, making the Cairo Derby one of football’s most electric matches.

fields.name: Ultras Ahlawy
fields.description: Ultras Ahlawy are the main supporters’ group of Al Ahly SC, Egypt’s most successful football club, founded in 2007. They are famous for their relentless chants, choreographed tifos, and massive displays of red and black that dominate the stands during matches, giving Al Ahly one of the most intimidating home atmospheres in Africa. The group is deeply tied to Egypt’s political and social landscape, playing a prominent role during the 2011 revolution and often clashing with authorities, which has made them both celebrated and controversial. Their fiercest rivalry is with Ultras White Knights of Zamalek, making the Cairo Derby one of the most explosive and passionate fixtures in world football.

fields.name: Ultras Yellow Dragons
fields.description: Ultras Yellow Dragons are the passionate supporters of Ismaily SC, one of Egypt’s oldest and most historic football clubs, based in Ismailia. Founded in the late 2000s, the group quickly became known for its loyalty and colorful support, bringing vibrant yellow choreographies, banners, and non-stop chants to matches. Unlike the much larger Cairo-based Ultras, the Yellow Dragons represent the pride of the Suez Canal region, emphasizing local identity and community spirit. Their biggest rivals are the Ultras of Al Ahly and Zamalek, but they maintain a reputation for being fiercely devoted yet more family-oriented compared to Egypt’s larger Ultras groups.

fields.name: Ultras Green Eagles
fields.description: Ultras Green Eagles are the devoted supporters of Al Masry SC, based in Port Said, Egypt, and were founded in 2007. They are famous for their passionate displays of loyalty to both their club and their city, often emphasizing Port Said’s independence and resistance spirit through their chants and banners. The Green Eagles are recognized for their creativity in tifos and choreographies, as well as their strong community ties, portraying themselves as defenders of Port Said’s honor. Their identity is forever linked to the tragic Port Said Stadium disaster in 2012, which left dozens of Al Masry and Al Ahly fans dead, a turning point in Egyptian football history. Despite bans and restrictions, the Green Eagles continue to symbolize pride, resilience, and fierce devotion to Al Masry.

fields.name: Çarşı Beşiktaş JK
fields.description: Founded in 1982, Çarşı are legendary for their creativity, humor, and political activism. Their iconic “A” in their logo is drawn like the anarchist symbol, and they are famous for witty banners, giant tifos, and socially engaged protests. They see themselves not just as supporters but also as a voice of the people, often critical of authorities.

fields.name: UltrAslan
fields.description: Established in 2001, UltrAslan are the largest supporter group in Turkey, known for their enormous numbers and intimidating atmospheres, especially in Ali Sami Yen and later Türk Telekom Stadium. They are fiercely loyal to Galatasaray and coordinate massive choreographies and deafening chants.

fields.name: Genç Fenerbahçeliler
fields.description: The biggest Fenerbahçe Ultras group, founded in the late 1990s. They are famous for their passionate support and rivalries with both Galatasaray and Beşiktaş. Their displays often feature huge banners, smoke, and continuous singing, making Şükrü Saracoğlu Stadium one of the toughest venues for opponents.

fields.name: Ultras Sur
fields.description: Ultras Sur are a notorious supporter group of Real Madrid CF, founded in 1980 and based in the Santiago Bernabéu’s south stand. They are famous for their extreme loyalty to Real Madrid, creating intimidating atmospheres with chants, banners, and tifos, but they are also widely criticized for far-right political associations and involvement in violence. Ultras Sur members are deeply involved in the rivalry with Atlético Madrid’s Frente Atlético and other clubs, making Madrid derbies highly charged both on and off the pitch. Despite being controversial, they remain one of the most recognized Ultras groups in Spain and Europe.

fields.name: Frente Atlético
fields.description: They are the main Ultras of Atlético Madrid, founded in 1982. Known for their fierce loyalty to Atlético, they fill the stands with relentless chants, tifos, and pyrotechnics, especially during Madrid derbies against Real Madrid’s Ultras Sur. The group has a reputation for violence and far-right political affiliations, which has led to clashes with rival fans and authorities. Despite controversy, they remain a defining part of Atlético’s intense fan culture.

fields.name: Boixos Nois
fields.description: are a well-known supporter group of FC Barcelona, founded in 1981. They are famous for their passionate support, banners, and choreographies, though their history has been marked by internal conflicts and far-right infiltration. Officially banned from the Camp Nou since 2003, they remain active in Barcelona’s fan scene, maintaining a reputation as one of the most extreme Ultras groups in Spain.

fields.name: La Adicción
fields.description: La Adicción are the main Ultras of Club América, founded in 1987 and based in Mexico City. They are renowned for their passionate support, creating intense atmospheres at Estadio Azteca with nonstop chants, giant banners, and coordinated tifos. Fiercely loyal to América, they are at the center of the club’s most heated rivalry with Chivas Guadalajara’s Barra 51, making the Clásico Nacional one of the most electric matches in Mexican football. Beyond football, they are known for their tight-knit community and commitment to supporting their team home and away.

fields.name: Barra 51 Sur
fields.description: the main Ultras of Chivas Guadalajara, also founded in the 1985. They are famous for their coordinated chants, banners, and tifos, emphasizing loyalty to Chivas and Mexican football traditions. Their rivalry with Club América’s La Adicción in the

fields.name: La Rebel
fields.description: the passionate Ultras of Pumas UNAM, founded in 1985–1986. Representing the university’s student spirit at Estadio Olímpico Universitario, they are known for energetic chants, drums, and vibrant banners, emphasizing academic pride and loyalty to UNAM. Their main rivalries are with Mexico City teams, particularly Club América, creating fierce local derbies.

fields.name: Green Brigade
fields.description: Green Brigade are the main Ultras of Celtic FC in Glasgow, Scotland, founded in 2006. They are known for their passionate support, massive tifos, and relentless chanting, creating one of the most intimidating and vibrant atmospheres in Scottish football. Strongly tied to Irish republicanism and left-wing political causes, the Green Brigade often incorporates political messages into their banners and displays, reflecting both football loyalty and social activism. Their main rivalries are with Rangers FC’s supporters in the Old Firm derby, which is one of the fiercest and most historic football rivalries in the world.

fields.name: The Red Ultras
fields.description: Supporters of Aberdeen FC, founded in the early 2000s. They are known for creating vibrant atmospheres at Pittodrie Stadium with chants, banners, and coordinated tifos. While smaller than the Glasgow clubs’ Ultras, they are fiercely loyal to Aberdeen and organize traveling support for away matches, emphasizing local pride and community identity.

fields.name: Kop of Boulogne
fields.description: Founded in 1987, Kop of Boulogne are one of the original Ultras groups supporting Paris Saint-Germain (PSG). Based in the Boulogne stand of Parc des Princes, they became famous for their vocal support, banners, and pyrotechnics. Historically, the group had internal political tensions and was associated with far-right ideology, which led PSG to officially distance itself from them in the 2000s. Their main rivalries were with other PSG Ultras (especially Supras Auteuil) and clubs like Olympique de Marseille in Le Classique, France’s most famous derby.

fields.name: Supras Auteuil
fields.description: Established in 1991, Supras Auteuil are another main PSG Ultras group, originally formed as a left-leaning alternative to Kop of Boulogne. Based in the Auteuil stand, they are known for choreographed tifos, constant chants, and traveling support for away matches. Supras Auteuil focused on social activism and club loyalty, and their rivalry with Boulogne was intense until both groups were banned from their respective stands in 2010 by the PSG management.

fields.name: Commando Ultras
fields.description: Supporting Olympique de Marseille, this group was founded in 1984 and is considered one of the oldest French Ultras. Located in the south stand of Stade Vélodrome, they are known for massive tifos, coordinated chants, and pyro displays. Commando Ultras have played a role in Marseille’s fan identity, emphasizing working-class pride and local loyalty. Their fiercest rivalry is with PSG Ultras in Le Classique, as well as local tensions with Virage Sud, another Marseille supporters’ group.

fields.name: Virage Sud
fields.description: supporters of Olympique de Marseille, Virage Sud were founded in 1987 to occupy the south curve alongside Commando Ultras. They focus on large-scale choreographies, organized chants, and pyro displays during matches. While sharing stadium space with Commando Ultras, they sometimes coordinate or compete for dominance in tifos and stadium leadership. Their main rivalries include PSG in Le Classique and other French clubs in Ligue 1

fields.name: Magic Fans
fields.description: Founded in 1987, Magic Fans support AS Saint-Étienne. They are famous for elaborate tifos, drums, and chants at Stade Geoffroy-Guichard, reflecting the club’s green-and-white identity. Their main rivalries are with Lyon, making the Derby Rhône-Alpes one of the fiercest local derbies in French football. They combine support for the club with strong regional pride.

fields.name: Curva Sud Milano
fields.description: Founded in 1967, Curva Sud Milano is the historic Ultras group supporting AC Milan, based in the south stand of San Siro. They are known for their massive tifos, coordinated chants, pyro, and constant drum support, creating one of Europe’s most intimidating atmospheres. Over the decades, they became a symbol of Milanese pride and loyalty. Their biggest rivalries include Inter Milan’s Curva Nord, Fiorentina, and Juventus, making them central to Serie A’s most intense derbies.

fields.name: Fossa dei Leoni
fields.description: One of the first true Italian Ultras groups, founded in 1968. Although officially dissolved in the 1990s, they laid the foundation for Milan’s fan culture, pioneering choreographies, flags, a

fields.name: Curva Nord Milano
fields.description: Founded in 1969, they are the main Ultras of Inter Milan, occupying the north stand of San Siro. Known for coordinated tifos, drums, and vocal support, they represent Inter’s fanbase in Milan. Their main rivalries are with Curva Sud (AC Milan) and Juventus. Political affiliations have varied over time, with some factions historically leaning right-wing.

fields.name: Irriducibili
fields.description: the Irriducibili are the historic Ultras of S.S. Lazio, based in the Curva Nord of Stadio Olimpico in Rome. They are notorious for elaborate tifos, political banners (often far-right), and intense support during matches. Their main rivalries include Roma’s Curva Sud, forming the Derby della Capitale, one of football’s fiercest city derbies.

fields.name: Curva Sud Roma
fields.description: Founded in 1979, this group supports AS Roma, occupying the south stand at Stadio Olimpico. They are known for large banners, choreographies, and passionate chants emphasizing Roman identity and pride. Their fiercest rivalry is with Lazio’s Irriducibili in the Derby della Capitale.

fields.name: Ultras Napoli
fields.description: One of Napoli’s main Ultras groups, founded in 1985. Famous for large tifos, pyro, and vocal support in Stadio Diego Armando Maradona, they represent the working-class spirit of Naples. They are fiercely loyal to Napoli and have rivalries with Juventus and Roma. Their displays often include social and political messages reflecting Neapolitan pride.

fields.name: Ultras Winners
fields.description: Established in 2003, they support Club Africain, Esperance’s fiercest rival. Beyond match-day support, they gained notoriety for their fiery displays during the Tunis Derby, sometimes causing matches to be delayed due to pyro and crowd intensity. The group emphasizes urban culture in Tunis, mixing football passion with a sense of community identity. Their political and social commentary is subtly integrated into chants and banners, making them influential both inside and outside the stadium.

fields.name: Ultras L'Emkachkhines
fields.description: they are the main Ultras of Esperance de Tunis. Famous for creating massive tifos and pyro shows in Stade Hammadi Agrebi, they are not just supporters but also active participants in Tunisian football culture. They played a crucial role during tense derbies against Club Africain, helping maintain fan pressure even during politically unstable periods in Tunisia. Their chants often reflect local pride and social identity, and they are known for organizing large traveling contingents to CAF Champions League matches, making Esperance one of the most intimidating clubs for visiting teams in Africa.

fields.name: Green Boys
fields.description: Founded in 2001, the Green Boys are one of the largest and most famous supporter groups of Raja Casablanca. Known for their massive tifos, pyro displays, and coordinated chants, they create an intimidating atmosphere at Stade Mohamed V. Beyond football, they are recognized for their strong social identity, representing the working-class neighborhoods of Casablanca. They also organize massive traveling contingents for African Champions League matches, giving Raja an international reputation. Their main rivalries are with Wydad Casablanca’s Ultras, forming the legendary Casablanca Derby, one of Africa’s fiercest football rivalries.

fields.name: Ultras Winners
fields.description: Established in 2005, they support Wydad Casablanca, Raja’s eternal rivals. Famous for spectacular banners, pyro shows, and relentless chants, they play a central role in the Casablanca Derby. The group is known for its strong community ties and active social presence in Casablanca neighborhoods. They occasionally engage in political or social commentary through banners and songs, reflecting local issues alongside football passion.
